sen.e: For old songs in Saibara, 'Agakoma' is in Volume 12 of "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves), 'Kazuraki' is a children's song sung during the enthronement of the Emperor Konin and in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) and "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the Nihon Ryouiki), 'Imogakado' is in Volume 11 of "Manyoshu", and 'Kawakuchi' is in 'Kokin Rokujo' (Kokin waka rokujo).

sen.j: 上に述べたような歌謡が貞観 (日本)年間ころにひとつの書物にまとめられ、ついで、一条雅信によって延喜20年ころ撰譜され（一説に藤原忠房によって作譜されるという）、以後、藤家および源家によって歌曲はつたえられた。
sen.e: Around Jogan era (Japan), songs described above were organized into one book, then Masanobu ICHIJO chose scores around 920 (one theory says that FUJIWARA no Tadafusa wrote scores), and later, songs were brought down by the To and Gen families.

sen.j: 藤家よりは源家ぼほうがさかえて、催馬楽の名人は源家のほうに多く出た。
sen.e: The Gen family were more prosperous than the To family, and the Gen family produced more masters of Saibara.

sen.j: こうして徐々に減ってゆき、戦国時代 (日本)に廃滅に瀕して、寛永3年9月四辻季継に詔があり「伊勢海」が復興された。
sen.e: Thus, Saibara songs were gradually decreased and almost extinct in the Sengoku period, but in September 1626, Suetsugu YOTSUTSUJI was given Mikotonori (imperial edict) and 'Ise no umi' was restored.
